Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics of Excited Electronic States in DNA
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Bern Kohler of Montana State University, together with his graduate and undergraduate students, will conduct a bottom-up investigation of excited electronic states created in single- and double-stranded DNA by the absorption of UV light. These excited states are the source of damaging photochemical reactions in living organisms. Widely tunable femtosecond lasers will be used to measure transient electronic and vibrational spectra of various DNA model systems in order to determine how the evolution of electronic energy is modified by base stacking and base pairing. Experiments will be performed on modified oligonucleotides in order to understand the effects of structural disorder on nonradiative decay pathways. Charge transfer excitations will be characterized by time-resolved vibrational spectra of DNA model systems containing modified and natural nucleobases and by comparison of experimental results with electronic structure calculations to be performed by collaborators. By probing vibrational modes that are sensitive to hydrogen bonding, mechanistic understanding of proton-coupled electron transfer in double-stranded DNA will be targeted.

Apart from its biological significance, DNA is an important model system for studying how energy deposited by light in a complex molecular structure evolves in time and is dissipated. By understanding how the response of the DNA double helix to UV light differs from the response of much smaller DNA building blocks, the research will benefit efforts that seek to predict and tailor the optical properties of other complex assemblies of light-active components, including nanomaterials. Prof. Kohler will also participate in a pilot project to deliver top-quality science education to rural Montana school children. Interactive science kits will be developed and mailed to select Montana teachers in underserved areas of the state. The goal is to give teachers and their students a richer learning experience through immersive, hands-on activities and to foster relationships with scientist role models from Montana?s land grant university through interactive videoconferencing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ultraviolet (UV) component of sunlight is responsible for detrimental health effects such as skin cancer. UV radiation from the sun is absorbed strongly by the DNA present in cells, promoting individual DNA molecules to so-called excited states that can sometimes lead to genetic mutations. For decades, there has been intense interest in understanding the molecular-level events initiated when a DNA molecule absorbs UV radiation. Beginning in 2000, extremely short laser pulses measuring 100 fs have been successfully used to study the deactivation of DNA excited states. These short pulse durations are essential because of the ultrashort lifetimes of excited states of single DNA nucleotides. Surprisingly, much longer-lived excited states are often observed when two or more nucleotides are present in a DNA strand. Understanding the nature of these long-lived excited states and how they differ from excited states in single DNA nucleotides were the major accomplishments of this work.

During the project period, femtosecond laser experiments were performed on a diverse collection of DNA compounds. Some compounds were purchased from commercial sources, while our collaborators at Northwestern University and at the University of Utah synthesized others. The model compounds investigated ranged from modified nucleobases to DNA strands containing up to 18 base pairs or 36 nucleotides. Studies of xanthines, compounds related to the naturally occurring nucleobases adenine and guanine, revealed ultrashort (< 1 ps) lifetimes. Increasing the number of methyl groups attached to xanthine slowed down the rate of energy transfer to the solvent, revealing that high frequency nucleobase vibrations play an important role in this process.

The modified guanine derivative 8-oxoguanine was also shown to have an ultrashort lifetime. However, incorporating 8-oxoguanine into a dinucleotide containing a second nucleotide (adenine) resulted in a much slower rate of decay. Through collaboration with a computational chemist in Italy and through the use of time-resolved infrared spectroscopy, we showed that the long-lived excited states form when light absorption moves an electron from one stacked base to another. This important result was published in 2014 in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Photoinduced electron transfer between stacked nucleobases explains the long-lived excited states seen in many kinds of DNA strands, and we were able to show that disrupting base stacking by adding alcohol or raising the solution temperature eliminates these states. Electron transfer forms a pair of radicals very efficiently in DNA strands. Fortunately, highly efficient charge recombination quenches these radicals on a picosecond time scale, reducing the threat of photochemical damage.

The other major discovery during the project period concerned how excited states observed in single strands are altered by the presence of a second DNA strand. We found that the UV-induced electron transfer observed in single strands still operates in double-stranded DNA, but now charge transfer produces a pair of radical ion base pairs. In several of the resulting base pair radical anions, a proton transfers from one strand to the other, yielding a rare tautomeric base pair or distonic (“distant”) radical ion in which spin and charge reside on opposite DNA strands. In essence, an electron hops between bases on the same strand, attracting a proton to it from the opposite strand. Although excited-state proton transfer underlies many theoretical concepts about DNA photostability, it has never been observed in DNA before. As in single strands, efficient charge recombination appears to mitigate the danger of radical damage to DNA. This work has revealed interesting parallels between DNA (where charge recombination is highly efficient) and organic photovoltaic materials where the prevention of charge recombination is of paramount importance.

Undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral researchers received training in advanced laser spectroscopy. These co-workers communicated their findings as journal publications, theses, and presentations at scientific meetings. This training resulted in outcomes such as acceptances to leading graduate programs and research positions at universities. Finally, a number of team members participated in outreach events that involved the public and elementary school students from rural Montana schools.
